content:
The Numbers

West Lancashire Borough Council's spending data reveals £333 million in external payments across 43,063 transactions with 4,614 unique suppliers spanning April 2016 to March 2026 — a full decade of financial data, one of the longest time series on the platform.

As a district council with an annual budget of approximately £14 million, West Lancashire is responsible for housing, planning, waste collection, leisure, and environmental health. Upper-tier services like education and social care are provided by Lancashire County Council.

Where the Money Goes

Supplier concentration is moderate, with an HHI of 213.3. The top supplier, WATES Property Services, accounts for 8.8% of total spend — a significant share for a single contractor, likely reflecting a major housing or building maintenance contract.

With 4,614 suppliers across a decade of data, West Lancashire has a broad supplier base overall, though the WATES dominance warrants monitoring to ensure competitive tension in future contract renewals.

Red Flags in the Data

West Lancashire scores 57.8 out of 100 on our fraud triangle composite — the lowest of the seven new councils added to the platform, suggesting relatively clean spending patterns. However, two findings stand out:

  • Benford's Law deviation of 8.2% — a WARNING-level anomaly. Benford's Law predicts the expected distribution of leading digits in naturally occurring numerical data. A deviation above 5% can indicate data manipulation, systematic rounding, or unusual payment patterns
  • Year-end spending spike of 12.7x the monthly average — March spending at nearly thirteen times normal levels, suggesting significant budget-rush behaviour at financial year-end

The Benford's Law result is noteworthy because West Lancashire has the highest max digit deviation of any district council on the platform except Wyre (7.6%). While this does not prove manipulation — threshold-based reporting (payments over £500) naturally distorts leading digit distributions — it merits further investigation.

Political Context

West Lancashire is controlled by Our West Lancs, a local independent group. The borough is primarily rural with the town of Skelmersdale as its largest settlement, originally designated as a New Town in the 1960s.

Data Quality

Ten years of spending data provides an exceptionally long baseline for trend analysis. The dataset covers pre-austerity, austerity, COVID, and post-COVID periods, enabling meaningful assessment of how spending priorities have shifted over time.

Explore the full dataset on our Spending page, or see our DOGE Investigation for deeper analysis.
